headline: Authentic Chinese Egg Rolls (from a Chinese person)
description: Chinese egg rolls that are easy and delicious with lots of rich flavor. You can't get much more authentic than this 300 year-old family recipe.

video.description: See how to make shredded pork egg rolls from a 300 year-old family recipe.
video.name: Authentic Chinese Egg Rolls

name: Authentic Chinese Egg Rolls (from a Chinese person)
recipeIngredient: 1 pound Chinese barbequed or roasted pork, cut into matchsticks
1 cup dried, shredded wood ear mushroom, rehydrated
4 cups oil for frying, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 1 teaspoon vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium heat. Pour in beaten eggs and cook, without stirring, until firmed up. Flip eggs over and cook for an additional 20 seconds to firm the other side. Set egg pancake aside to cool, then slice into thin strips.

Heat remaining vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Stir in cabbage and carrot; cook for 2 minutes to wilt. Add pork, bamboo shoots, mushroom, green onions, soy sauce, salt, sugar, and MSG; continue cooking until vegetables soften, about 6 minutes. Stir in sliced egg, then spread the mixture out onto a pan, and refrigerate until cold, about 1 hour.

To assemble the egg rolls: Place a wrapper onto your work surface with one corner pointing towards you. Place about 3 tablespoons of cooled filling in a heap onto the bottom third of the wrapper. Brush a little beaten egg white onto the top two edges of the wrapper, then fold the bottom corner over the filling and roll firmly to the halfway point. Fold the left and right sides snugly over the egg roll, then continue rolling until the top corners seal the egg roll with the egg white. Repeat with remaining egg roll wrappers, covering finished egg rolls with plastic wrap to keep from drying out.
Heat about 6 inches of oil in a wok or deep-fryer to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Fry egg rolls 3 or 4 at a time until golden brown, 5 to 7 minutes. Drain on paper towels.

review.reviewBody: Very Good and easy to make. My husband says they are the best egg rolls he has had in the area. Makes a great dinner.

So good! I did change a little bit but kept the directions the same. Used fresh bean sprouts for the shoots and chopped shrimp for the meat. Couldn't find the mushrooms called for so used a rehydrated shiitake. I added a bit of hoisin and oyster sauce with the low sodium tamari (vs soy). And threw in some chopped cilantro because I had it. Will make these again. I like the way you make everything ahead of time, so it makes dinner appear simple. Thank you for a fantastic recipe!
Had no idea packaged egg roll wrappers and MSG existed 300 years ago.. great recipe, solid egg rolls and some Chinese history. Win, win, win!

Omitted bamboo shoots and MSG. Used ground pork instead of roasted and subbed chopped shiitake mushrooms instead of dried woodear mushrooms. Really good!! Deep fried the first 6 but changed gears halfway through and pan fried the rest instead. Doing so absorbed less grease and we liked the texture better. It also cooked quicker! Would absolutely make again! Personal preference; next time would add onions, garlic and ginger. Still delicious and husband and I enjoyed very much! Thank you!
Most suspicious recipe ever.

Aside from the 300 year old recipe thing, these did taste like the real thing invented in NYC during the 1930’s. I doubled the MSG, because go big or go home. It’s an egg roll people, cutting a couple of corners is like smoking half a cigarette instead of the whole thing. It doesn’t make it “healthier”.
Really enjoyed this. My son made the wrappers from scratch using another recipe.

The first time I made it, I followed the instructions exactly and they were awesome! For New Year's Eve I made them again, but this time I substituted turkey from Thanksgiving (kept in freezer) for the pork and finely chopped water chestnuts for the bamboo shoots (I just didn't have any). These egg rolls were delicious also! (I did want to note that when we were traveling in China, the people did not know what egg rolls are. Either way, thank you for the recipe!)

Great recipe; five stars! There were a few obvious omissions in the directions: cabbage, 1/2 carrot, bamboo shoots, and dried mushrooms need to be shredded or sliced thinly. I used Savoy, or Napa, cabbage, but as a time saver, packaged cole slaw mix can be used. Also, soak Dehydrated mushrooms in hot water until rehydrated before adding to wok. (I just microwaved them in a glass measuring cup with twice the water, then drained them well.) Also, drain finished filling before chilling. I find using Chinese barbecue pork is delicious in this recipe, but to save time, ground pork is a time saver and is also quite good.
wonderful..just wonderful...my mom stuffed herself on these and she usually eats like a bird.
I changed some ingredients but used most of them. They were great. This recipe is great!

Great recipe. I cannot count how many times I have made these eggrolls. I have made it exactly as written and I have also made it using shrimp or ground beef instead of the pork. I also seasoned the cabbage mixture with lawry's seasoning salt when using either of the latter two.

Great recipe. I cannot count how many times I have made these eggrolls. I have made it exactly as written and I have also made it using shrimp or ground beef instead of the pork. I also seasoned the cabbage mixture with lawry's seasoning salt when using either of the latter two.
Can be cooked in an air fryer.Brush each egg roll before cooking with cooking oil. Air fry 4 at a time at 350 for 12 minutes. They come out nice and crispy without being greasy.
COULDN'T FIND THE WOODEAR ADDED MORE CARROT

These were time consuming to make but totally worth it. We couldn't find MSG but otherwise followed the recipe as it was written and they were fantastic. They were the best homemade egg rolls I have ever had!

These were time consuming to make but totally worth it. We couldn't find MSG but otherwise followed the recipe as it was written and they were fantastic. They were the best homemade egg rolls I have ever had!
Oh yeah! This is a KEEPER! Thanks Ling Family for sharing!
Better than my local Chinese restaurant!
great egg rolls and very easy to make
It is well enough for a Chinese American dish. I find it extremely difficult to believe it is 300 years old, as msg was not invented untill the early 1900's.

Thank you very much for sharing your family's 300 year-old recipe. Our friends who are originally from Shanghai came over for dinner and we made these. I used the 'lumpia' wrappers as we (and they) like the thin, crispy shell. These eggrolls were absolutely delectable and the varied assortment of veggies, mushrooms with the Chinese bbq pork blended into a very tasty medley. My daughter said they were the best eggrolls I have ever made. We served them with a blend of rice vinegar with a touch of balsalmic vinegar for dipping which are friends loved. Thanks again!

Fantastic recipe. 
Just Omit the MSG, it doesn't need it.
I made my own fried pork to add to this recipe: 
ground pork, finely chopped ginger, green onions
soy sauce, sesame seed oil, black pepper
And instead of frying the eggrolls, I use the Air Fryer... delicious!
300 year old recipe and apparently they had MSG?
Happy
leave out the msg that chemical has not been around near 300 years and its not good for you otherwise I would give this 5 stars. I substituted fresh baby bella mushrooms and fresh green onion.

I made several changes to this recipe based on the ingredients I had on hand. The protein I used was shrimp and Andouille sausage. Added some spices, garlic and onion powder, pepper, red pepper flakes, and cayenne pepper. I fried them in 1/2 inch oil and turned them over until brown. They were very good.

I made these egg rolls tonight and they were GREAT! I didn't add bamboo shoots or mushrooms, but instead added bean sprouts and they were so yummy. Our two kids and the husband ate all 15 that I made within the hour. Thank you for sharing your recipe. I will be making these again very soon.
I made those and we loved them! .. no more frozen egg rolls for us! thank you for this amazing recipe!

I'm rating five stars because I believe this is the best base recipe I've ever used; individual preferences should not be considered, in my opinion, such as the addition or omissions of MSG, or the things I did which were to my liking. I did not use MSG, I added a tablespoon of hoisin sauce, 1/2lb of ground pork that I cooked before adding the veggies, and I used portobello mushrooms as my store had none other to choose from the day I went shopping. My 7 year old daughter helped me, & this recipe was fun & easy. My family really enjoyed the flavor, & I'll make these every time!

This recipe has a lot more meat than vegetables. I didn't use the MSG and I added a little shredded cabbage and double the green onions (I love green onions) I'm almost finished with the egg rolls (I eat them myself) and I plan to make more
Best egg rolls I have ever had! I left out the msg, but everything else was about the same. I don't really follow recipe's to a t, I use them more as a guide. Was good later and re-heated too.

I added 2 cloves garlic, 1 tsp. ginger, 1 tsp. pepper, 1 tsp. soy sauce and I would have liked to use 1 tsp. sesame oil for the eggs but my girlfriend didn't want it in there and I didn't use the MSG because she is allergic to it and its not really needed. I think I'll use shitake mushrooms next time. I would also suggest raising the temperature of the deep fryer to 375F. Oh and the filling was twice as much as I needed so I'll add another package of wrappers. I would suggest using lumpia wrappers.
First time making egg rolls. The recipe was easy to follow and the results were delicious! I wouldn't change a thing to this recipe.

I will definitely make this again. My husband said they were better than any he has ever had. Better than ones from a Chinese restaurant. He is already requesting me to make them again. The only thing I did different was add just an eighth tsp. of Chinese five spice. These are amazing.
Excellent!! Turned out so good and yummy!!

Loved these, used minced shrimp instead of meat, and added a 1/2 teaspoon of fresh ginger. These where so good, I'm making triple recipe and freeze for future use. I guarantee these are better than a takeout egg roll.

we omit the meat and add our meatless substitute (crisp fried button mushrooms and onions) and do not add msg, or bamboo shoots. I add Maifun noodles to absorb extra juices and beansprouts. it takes a while to make the first time but the more often you make them the faster you'll get. They freeze very well.

I'm so glad I finally tried this recipe! I've been using a recipe that has potential, but there was always something missing. This recipe showed me the error of my ways and helped me to make a delicious egg roll. I omitted the pork, mushrooms, bamboo, and MSG, to keep it basic, but they were still a delicious side to my "Chinese" dinner theme tonight. These were paired with my homemade vegetable fried rice and the General Tsao's Chicken recipe from this site.

I'm so glad I finally tried this recipe! I've been using a recipe that has potential, but there was always something missing. This recipe showed me the error of my ways and helped me to make a delicious egg roll. I omitted the pork, mushrooms, bamboo, and MSG, to keep it basic, but they were still a delicious side to my "Chinese" dinner theme tonight. These were paired with my homemade vegetable fried rice and the General Tsao's Chicken recipe from this site.
absolutely delicious! Will make these again and again and again. I couldn't cook them fast enough before my family gobbled them up off the plate. 5 stars for sure. Highly recommend this recipe

I thought these were great! Love the egg addition. I didn't have any pork or mushrooms. I also didn't have MSG, but I probably wouldn't have used it anyway. I replaced the items I didn't have with chicken, celery, and onion. I also put a little garlic powder in there, since other egg roll recipes were telling me to, and I thought it sounded like a good idea. You know, because garlic is awesome! (Italian chick over here who loves her garlic.... and Asian food..?)

OMG, these were so good!! I even made the BBQ pork myself to try to get the best flavour I could. These were so good and once the prep work was done, very fast and easy to make. They even heated up well the next day, not that there were many left over!! for the record, I did omit the MSG though as I don't feel well sometimes after eating it. I also substituted shiitake mushrooms the for dried wood ear mushrooms as I couldn't find any in my little town! I don't think that either of those things took away from the original recipe. Thank you, Mendy Ling, for submitting the recipe.

Wow. Just wow. I've been on a kick of trying recipes I never thought I would be able to do right, and this turned out incredible. I downsized the filling to cabbage, bean sprouts, and carrot (all I had in the house), cooked and in oil and soy sauce and fried as directed. Watch the video for making this recipe on the site -- it will INFINITELY make rolling your egg rolls (and possibly other dishes) much easier. My local restaurants charge $6-7 for an order of 4 egg rolls ... never again will I pay that, as this recipe was just as good or better, and at a fraction of the cost. My boyfriend and I intended to make it as an appetizer, and we just put away the entree and ate this as our whole meal. Can't wait to try it with other variations, next time with the mushrooms and green onions in the original recipe! Thanks Mendy!
I brushed the egg rolls with olive oil and baked them in a 425* oven for 15 minutes. I didn't use bamboo or mushrooms, used what I had. They are delicious!

This is the closest recipe to the one my Vietnamese mother in law has been making for fifty years. She even admitted that the egg is her secret ingredient but that she just scrambles the one egg she uses instead of three into the entire egg roll mixture instead of making the 'pancake' and cutting it up. Also, it's important to remove the stems from the mushrooms after rehydrating them as they are very hard to get soft enough and stay very woody. We also give everything a fine chop not just julienned, carrots shredded. When sealing the rolls, we usually just use cornstarch and water but the egg white worked well. We also use peanut oil for frying so I recommend that if allergies aren't an issue. These egg rolls were full of flavor and the only suggestion to the seasoning is a teaspoon of rice wine vinegar and a teaspoon of sesame oil in place of one teaspoon of soy sauce. Strain the oil and store in the fridge and it can be reused for the same purpose several times.
there ok there not the best

I had a good size cooked pork steak left over from last night, and cut it into matchsticks for this recipe. Other than that, I didn't change a thing. This is a delicious recipe with all the tastes and texture we want in a good egg roll. I think the time the mixture sits in the fridge to cool, really helps to meld those favors. We have tried many different recipes over the years, but this is the keeper now! It's very good!! Thanks so much for posting a family recipe, and allowing us to enjoy it. :)

This is an excellent recipe exactly as directed. These egg rolls were much tastier than any we have had in Asian restaurants. I did cheat a little and used the bagged Cole slaw mix instead of bok Choy, but did not change anything else. Will definitely keep all these ingredients on hand to make again and again!

I made these as written except omitted the MSG. I liked the filling quite well. However, they were just so ooo oily! I know that frying = oil, but that said the oil was overpowering for my taste. I drained them on paper towels but maybe just not enough? Anyway I might try it again but bake instead.
these egg rolls are the best I've tried. My family loved them and these are definately a keeper!! Followed the recipe.
Just finished making this and I have to say they are wonderful! Easy to make and taste so good!
We loved these! Recipe was easy to follow and my family devoured the egg rolls!

I have been making my own egg rolls for years but this recipe got so many great reviews I decided to try it. I did use pork - ground some shoulder and browned it. I only used 1/2 pound and increased veggies using straw mushrooms, bean sprouts, coleslaw mix (cheated. Loved the egg in the mix and did add some sesame oil. Will make again and add some garlic and ginger. Delicious.

The recipe was strictly average, as tasty as spring rolls typically are but nothing out of the ordinary. As for the person who questions the presence of MSG in a 300 year old recipe, you're right... mostly. Crystalline MSG was not invented until the early 20th century, when a Japanese researcher isolated it from konbu seaweed, but the compound is nothing but the sodium salt of glutamate, one of the most common naturally-occurring amino acids (sorry about the chemistry lecture). Soy, tomatoes, seaweed, and many other foods are rich in glutamates, too. So yes, you are right. Ms. Ling's ancestors did not whip out the Accent to make spring rolls, but the salt may have been a stand-in or substitute for another glutamate-containing ingredient. It's as anachronistic as using powdered citric acid as a substitute for lemon juice. I have a harder time believing that a person who lived 300 years ago would have used that much oil (a very, very expensive ingredient) to fry up something to go with tea.
These were really fun to make and super delicious! The recipe made so may that I was able to freeze the leftovers.

Fantastic. Delicious. And such a fun project. I used the Chinese Pork Tenderloin recipe on this site. My husband doesn't love eggs, so we left out that part. I used the smallest cabbage I could find, 1 large carrot, and left out the mushrooms and MSG. This recipe only used 1/2 a package of wrappers, so I had to throw the rest away :( Also, the package said to use a mixture of flour & water to seal the egg rolls, so I did that instead of using the egg white. And 4 cups of oil isn't really necessary-just use enough to cook about 4 egg rolls at once. These were so tasty (especially with a homemade sweet & sour sauce on the side) and leftovers were easily re-crisped in the oven :)

Great basic recipe for eggrolls. We omitted the MSG and bamboo shoots and eggs due to allergies. We added a teaspoon of sesame oil and some pepper the eggroll seasoning. We used three tablespoons of flour and three tablespoons of water to make a paste to seal the eggrolls instead of eggs. Had some roasted shredded pork which really made this eggroll stand out. We made all different sizes and they were all great!

I never had the courage to try making egg rolls; yet, Asian food os my favorite! I took a chance and tried these. I had to WILL myself to do it, even though I'm an established cook. Bottom line: WONDERFUL! These egg rolls were so easy to make, they turned out restaurant quality, as promised. I made them exactly as the recipe said. The only other comment I would make it to make the entire batch and then freeze the leftovers. I made the mistake of trying to freeze them un-fried. Stupid move! Mendy, please give me more authentic Chinese recipes! Especially mooshu and Governor's Chicken!

THESE ARE WONDERFUL!!!! I was short on time so I had to make some adjustments, and it still turned out very good. First I didn't have the meat called for in the recipe. In the other reviews I saw several who used the Chinese Pork Tenderloin recipe. I didn't have time to cook a tenderloin so I took the ingredients from the Chinese Pork Tenderloin recipe and added them to raw sausage that I browned. Mmmmm... I also didn't have any msg. Other than those two changes I made the recipe as written. It won rave reviews by everyone. Will definately make these again!

I make these often, for years.easier way is to use a package of shredded cole slaw... don't cook the slaw,mix your meat (i like crumbled sausage,shredded bake chicken breast& sometimes chopped shrimp),in the slaw. roll&cook. the slaw will cook when you cook the egg roll and they are crispy but not raw. Not as much work either.

Really good recipe. These are very similar to the egg rolls my mom makes. I think MSG is essential. It balances out all the flavors. For those who say MSG is unhealthy, get educated. Read up on it and know that it isn't harmful.
Very good. Left off the Msg
good!! I used coleslaw instead of cabbage, a mix of wild mushrooms since i couldn't find wood ear and I marrinated the pork roast in "Irene's Barbeque Sauce" (from this site) and baked.
This is the first time that I see bbq or roasted pork is used. I use lean grounded pork. MSG?? Really? No vermicelli noodle?
very good! I am a bit turned off by MSG, so I used none. it was fine without it.
I was a little bit dubious about this recipe, but decided to give it a go anyway. I followed your recipe verbatim using my Chinese BBQ pork. What a surprise, it was excellent! Thank You…

These were by far the best egg rolls I have ever eaten! I did as others suggested and made the Chinese Pork Tenderloin recipe from this site. I then used the marinade that was left in the pan after cooking the tenderloin to saute the vegetables for the egg rolls (instead of adding the soy sauce, salt, sugar and MSG this recipe called for). I also used a bag of shredded cole slaw as suggested by others. The result was perfect. P.S. You don't need egg white to seal the wrappers. You can just use water.
Um? 300 year old MSG, huh? I doubt the authenticity of this recipe, and the results were fine. Nothing fantastic, tasted like any other egg roll I've ever had. But It definitely wasn't bad.
thanks! I will try this authentic egg roll recipe.
These were delicious, but it seemed like something was missing - but I can't figure out what.
the last time i made these my son ate about 15 all by himself, now if i am going to make them i have to sit and make around 60 egg rolls and everyone sniffs them out!
Very, very good. Only thing is that I needed to packages of wrappers- which is great since my family ate them so fast!
Absolutely Phenomenal. These were the best eggrolls every. Better than any chinese restaurant I have been to.

These are so easy and excellent! I was able to do all of the chopping & cooking and still get them on the table in 70 minutes by skipping the refrigeration step. I had lots of leftover filling even though I used more than 3 T. per egg roll...so next time I'll buy two packages of egg roll wrappers. Also, I fried the entire batch of egg rolls in about 1/4 inch of oil...it isn't necessary to fry them in 6 inches of oil! I just kept slowly turning them in the oil; they cook very quickly so check on them often. I used unseasoned cooked chicken breast instead of barbequed or roast pork and omitted the MSG, but added a little black pepper--the flavor turned out great.

The husband and I loved these! I ended up using the ground pork and omitted the mushrooms as they just gross me out. Oh...I didn't use the MSG either. I thought the flavor was great and will definitely use this recipe in the future. Next time I will try the recipe to the T as my husband DOES enjoy mushrooms as does his family. Thank you for sharing!

Made some adjustments to my desire: Did not included MSG (unhealthy), bamboo or pork. Used regular white mushrooms instead of wood ear mushroom. Added ginger, garlic, a pinch of cayenne, water chestnut, bean spouts, toasted sesame oil, and scrabbled eggs in the cabbage mixture. YUMMY!!
Delicious. Loved it.

I used a pre-cut cold slaw bag of cabbage & carrots and used ground chix thighs instead of pork. Rolled them all then kept them warm after frying in the oven at 250* while cooking other things. They stayed crisp. These take a lot of time but they are worth it!
Yummy! They were lots fun to make.
Amazing. Well worth the effort.

I made these exactly as written except for MSG, and unfortunately I don't have easy access to wood ears. I used portabella cut into match sticks since I had a few on hand. Next time I make them I will add some hoisin or oyster sauce for a little additional kick. I also think allowing the cabbage mixture to rest longer will infuse it with more flavor.
These were fantastic! I used button mushrooms instead of wood ear, Chinese cabbage, honey instead of sugar, and a ginger, garlic, red pepper spice mix instead of MSG. Will make again and again!

These were the BEST! My family started eating them before I finished cooking them. I didn't have BBQ pork so I subbed with a 4oz. can of tiny shrimp. Also used a bag of slaw (cabbage, carrot, broccoli & cauliflower) and added some bean sprouts as another recipe called for. The egg rolls were fresh and very tasty. A little time consuming but was thinking I could keep the cabbage mixture in the fridge and fry up whatever portion I might need for a meal. Thanks for the REAL recipe:)

Egg rolls are my favorite chinese-type food.....I loved them. Not too difficult to make either...except you better know how to make chinese barbecued or roasted pork...which isn't difficult either! :0)

I left out the bamboo shoots and the mushrooms because I didn't have them but WOW are these good. I did add a pinch of ginger but wish I wouldn't have. Next time I might up the sugar a pinch. Serve with hot mustard.

Fantastic! I didn't use barbequed pork (and I'm sure this would have sent it over the top), but rather, boiled some chicken breast and shredded it - as it's what I had on hand. Next time, I'd add some hoisin sauce or some type of a smoky/bbq flavoring if using chicken. Left out the MSG (absolutely no need for this preserving ingredient, I'd think!), AND, didn't fry them.. but rather, baked at 400 for about 15-20 minutes - until golden. Just make sure to spray the baking sheet with oil and also to spray the tops of the eggrolls with oil. Such an easy, healthy (when baked!), eggroll recipe! No need for any sauce, but I bet a sweet and sour would be quite yummy. :)

OMG!! These were AMAZING!! I made these for company and they couldn't believe I had made them myself. It does take a lot of time and prep but it makes a lot and they freeze really well. Re-heat in the oven and just as good.

OMG I made these for my annual Christmas Eve dinner and they were really a hit. Thanks so much for the recipe and it is a keeper for now on. I got phone calls for the whole week asking if I would make more!
this turns out great... I didn't at he msg but we still loved it
My brother and I were trying different recipes, I made this one, and he made another one; his won hands down. This one didn't taste very good.

This egg roll recipe is the best yet!. We used boneless spare ribs from our local Chinese restaurant instead of roast pork, and just pulsed in the food processor to avoid too much cutting. We also omitted the mushrooms since we didn't have them on hand, and also left out the MSG. Other than that, we followed the recipe and directions and boy were they good! We'll definitely be making this often!
This recipe is absolutely wonderful!

I have made these many times but usually sub different mushrooms because I have them on hand. Finally remembered to get the wood ear and they do make a big difference. As others have mentioned I use "Chinese Pork Tenderloin" when I make with meat but more often than not I make these all veggie but include the spices from the Pork Tenderloin recipe as well. Have had people say these are the best egg rolls they have ever had. I usually deep fry but this time I wok fried with just about an inch deep of oil, very good results.

These are amazing! I can honestly say I would rather make these than order out..much better. I use a bag of coleslaw in place of the cabbage and carrots and use whatever meat I have around (today I used the chicken I was putting in the chicken fried rice). I omit the MSG, bamboo shoots, and mushrooms..simply because my husband is picky and he likes the basics. This recipe can easily be altered to suit just about anyone. Definitely a keeper!
minus the MSG, bamboo, and mushrooms. My fam loved it! even made some with salad shrimp, wanted something quik....yumm!
I made this recipe, minus the MSG. It was amazing! I forwarded the link to every cook I know. I literally can't stop shoving them in my mouth:)
Used 3 tablespoons oil, 2 carrots, 1 chicken breast, 1 tablespoon soy sauce, szechuan marinade, pepper, and 2 egg whites. No eggs, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, pork, and MSG. Might need more flavor.

I made them for my family and they absolutely loved the egg rolls. The following day my son popped the left overs in the oven and they were as crispy as the previous day. Delicious, though I will note that I did not add mushroom because I did not have them handy and they were still awesome. We must try them with the mushrooms next time.

item.name: Authentic Chinese Egg Rolls (from a Chinese person)
